descriptions.text1:
"Anomalous hull designated codeword 'Facet'. Motion to create security level SUPER ALABASTER passed and content of 'Facet' encounter debriefing made classified at this level.

High Hegemon, if I may speak freely, keeping an entire flotilla quiet on this one is going to be a real challenge for COMSEC."
descriptions.text2: Unidentified Vessel
descriptions.text3:
UNKNOWN ENTRY

Please register your Tri-Tachyon datapad to receive the latest news and updates.

descriptions.text1: "This is the largest of the anomalous vessel class thus far encountered. Not even a partial specimen has been recovered, much to the consternation of the VP of Research. Some members of the board - unofficially of course - are asking about sabotage or mutiny. I don't think you're quite getting the reality of the situation through to them."
descriptions.text2: Unidentified Vessel
descriptions.text3:
UNKNOWN ENTRY

Please register your Tri-Tachyon datapad to receive the latest news and updates.

descriptions.text1:
"The only mercy is that it is short-lived."

- intercepted audio log, speaker unknown
descriptions.text2: Unidentified Entity

descriptions.text1:
"Said the chief was mad when he came back, they did, but he weren't. Not at first, anyway. That's the tragedy, see, it was all them that said he lied that drove him there."

- overheard on the Jangala Station concourse
descriptions.text2: Unidentified Entity

descriptions.text1:
"If this interpretation is to be believed, it gives a whole new life, of sorts, to arguments surrounding the cosmic censorship hypothesis."

- intercept, [REDACTED]
descriptions.text2: Unidentified Entity

descriptions.text1:
"A self-stabilizing anomalous incursion, it builds charge as it spins - if our sensors are correct, in many more dimensions than are first apparent. This self-sustaining action produces massive energy differentials which are periodically discharged toward its, um, target. I'd never have said a storm could be evil, but now..."

- intercepted audio log, speaker unknown
descriptions.text2: Unidentified Entity

descriptions.text1:
"When the end comes, as it must soon come, it will be as a yawning abyss darker than fear and filled of teeth. It will come to swallow hope, it will, it will come to swallow sin, it will, and the only escape is the Path, it is. The Path!"

- selection from the Archives of Holy Inquisition, Hesperus
descriptions.text2: Unidentified Entity

descriptions.text1:
An advanced troop transport employing phase stealth technology, this design was put to effective use by Tri-Tachyon black ops during the Second AI War. The Phantom should avoid ship-to-ship combat as integrated armor and weaponry are only rated effective versus light ground targets.

"The system patrols should have seen the Tachies coming, but didn't. ADA was tracking the bogey right up until it disappeared off the scope, leaving the ground guns spinning in circles trying to reacquire a target. We saw a shadow in the air, like dark wings falling on the compound. Don't remember much else. Suit rec says incoming fire already took the rest of the squad."
- The Fall of Bunker 58

A stealth freighter which audaciously employs phase technology to support covert fleet operations, the Revenant is not cheap or efficient. Raised up from a dusty set of databanks hidden in an unnamed rock orbiting a nondescript star for a hundred cycles after the First AI War, the Revenant schematics provided an immense boon to the logistics of Tri-Tachyon raiders during the Second AI War.

Hegemony lawyers considered declaring the design illegal, but evidence of alpha-level AI influence was deemed insufficient. The lead prosecutor insisted so strongly that this was itself evidence of the work of an alpha that the High Hegemon found it politic to recuse them from the proceedings.

The Champion-class heavy cruiser is a versatile warship featuring a range of powerful energy weapons; the crowning element is a heavy energy turret mounting, rare among midline ships. This offensive array is backed by a robust energy grid capable of supercharging the energy weapon loadout, increasing damage output to devastating levels. A heavy missile hardpoint complements the loadout by enabling the Champion to unleash a crippling strike without taxing flux levels. The Champion is a solid and capable contender, able to face capital ships on the battle-line.

A relatively recent design, the Champion is a product of the historically recent "Cruiser School" naval revolution that never saw active service in the pre-collapse Domain Armada. Although prototypes were constructed and forge-ready specifications distributed to several battlegroups, the Champion was never cleared for active deployment due to an ongoing lawsuit between Altair Exotech and Orion Shipyards. Each megacorp accused the other of industrial espionage and inappropriately influencing the Armada officers overseeing the procurement process. The truth was more complex, inflaming longstanding rivalries in the officer corps as the investigatory committee called witness after witness. The Collapse prevented any sort of conclusive ruling from reaching the Persean Sector however, and now the entire matter is considered irrelevant. With the discovery of Champion plans on a Domain armaments courier, the warship was quickly put into service by the fleet of the Persean League, among others.

A fast-attack high-tech light cruiser, the Fury is designed to choose when and where it strikes to inflict maximum effect upon the enemy. The specialized inbuilt plasma 'microburn' system allows the Fury to make small dashes at high speed to catch unwary opponents off-guard.

The Fury-class is the Shrike-classes big sibling, a product of the same design team asked to fulfill slightly updated requirements, including resolution of the longstanding hull corrosion issue without, it was hoped, introducing any new problems. This was largely successful (once the chaos of several indignant resignations was sorted out).

Dismissed by heavy-armor-ballistic-firepower traditionalists as 'just another small-bore glass cannon', the Fury has nonetheless proven quite dangerous in the hands of quick-thinking fleet commanders.

An ancient and tough heavy frigate featuring robust construction, a combat burn drive, and no modern shields. Instead, the Vanguard is equipped with an integrated Damper Field of archaic design but tuned to modern standards. This allows the Vanguard to allocate 100% of flux buildup to weapon systems, leaving defense to its heavy armor enhanced by the obscure physics of resonant field-dampening.

This design is old enough to be contemporary with early models of the Onslaught battleship, though unlike that illustrious pillar of the Domain Navy the Vanguard was retired from service long before the collapse of the Gate network. In the post-Collapse chaos it was a chance discovery by an enterprising arms dealer that saw relatively complete schematics of the Vanguard-class heavy frigate lifted from an overlooked museum exhibit. The atavistic and aggressive design opens an unexpected niche for the Vanguard in modern fleets - with the added advantage that all essential components have been declassified for ages, and are of simple make; even repair of catastrophic damage is relatively straightforward.

The Manticore is loved by frontier officers for its ability to rapidly bring firepower to bear in small engagements and loathed by Domain strategic planners for interfering with the orderly schema of official fleet doctrine. The Manticore's oversized primary weapon mount and built-in rangefinder are a gunner's dream but allow this destroyer to easily overextend itself in battle. That, operators argue, is what the canister flak system is for - and stripping the paint off your allied ships, as the old joke goes. 

A healthy respect for intimidating firepower in a small package see this design continue in the service of fleets of the Persean Sector. When the opportunity presents itself, pirates are particularly keen to recover a Manticore hull and apply blood-red livery to their overgunned prize.

A resilient design often overlooked by history, the Eradicator-class fast cruiser features powerful dual engine nacelles that allow it to deliver uncompromising firepower and a powerful missile barrage to the weakest point of the enemy battleline - or come to the rescue of valuable assets that have found themselves tactically exposed.

Back in the long cycles of the Domain, a chance accident during a fleet demonstration set one of an Eradicator's engine nacelles into shutdown and the other into overdrive, putting the ship into a terrible spin only stopped by a heroic effort from the engineering crew. Worse than the injuries and casualties suffered was the ship class becoming the laughingstock of a significant portion of the Domain hypermedia sphere. To save face the admiralty quietly assigned all of the Eradicators to frontier duty, far from the fickle attentions of the core sector budget committees. It would take a generation and several difficult fringe rebellion mop-up operations before a new fast-cruiser class model was requested by the Domain Navy to replace the Eradicator's role in front-line battlefleets.

The largest and most prominent shrine of the Luddic faith, the Shrine of Gilead is most closely associated with the prophet Ludd's physical presence and influence in the Persean Sector.

Pilgrims walk where Ludd walked, though the world is much changed from Ludd's day. A deep forest, carefully gardened over more than a hundred cycles, has replaced the towering industrial terraforming machines that once surrounded the shrine complex. Protected by the Knights and shepherded by Church, the shrine is intended to be a physical representation of Ludd's vision.
Dedicated to those whose life has been torn away by wrath and war, the Shrine of Killa is grim, desolate, and half-forgotten even by the faithful of the Church.

The Shrine of Volturn has fallen upon hard times under the Sindrian Diktat's occupation. Few pilgrims risk arrest and harassment by the secret police, and few remember the sacred place dedicated to a delicate balance - now, perhaps, upset - of invading Earth life's effects on once pristine worlds.

Subject of much controversy (and not a few lurid horror-holos), the Shrine of Jangala observes the glory and wonder of the xeno-jungles of Jangala. Particularly devoted pilgrims are known to expose themselves to the xenolife, an uncomfortable practice under the best conditions, and potentially deadly.

Despite the destructive power of the orbital burns, Jangala's flora grows inexorably, filling every gap and seam with alien tendrils, to displace human attempts to domesticate the planet.
The Knights of Ludd claim the Shrine of Hesperus as their own; it is dedicated to the struggle and death of the many martyrs that follow in Ludd's path.

The Beholder Station Shrine is dedicated to contemplation of the stunning diversity of life which can be found in even the harshest environments of Creation. Below the station's orbit, Kumari Aru's bands of clouds and huge storm systems shroud a rich ecosystem unique to this gas giant.  

A small few scholars who meet Church approval are allowed to study of Kumarian xenolife here, though active sampling missions and energetic sensor sweeps have been forbidden for many cycles in order to not disturb the delicate balance of life.

The Gorgon was designed as a lightweight delivery system for an energy strike fired from unexpected attack vectors calculated to initiate beyond the range of the heaviest anticipated PD coverage. A solid DEM packing reliable burst attack power.

The Gorgon was designed as a lightweight delivery system for an energy strike fired from unexpected attack vectors calculated to initiate beyond the range of the heaviest anticipated PD coverage. A solid DEM packing reliable burst attack power.

This pod-based autoloader allows more missiles to be delivered on-target over the course of a combat encounter, but requires a larger mount-point.

The Gazer DEM forces a cruel choice upon targeted vessels, particularly those with a shallow flux pool - raise shields and build excess flux while raked by the Gazer's graviton beam, or drop shields and open oneself to more direct attack.

Reception of the Gazer is as split: some commanders consider this an elegant weapon from a more civilized age, others, a design which compromises raw firepower for finicky guidance and targeting systems.

The Gazer DEM forces a cruel choice upon targeted vessels, particularly those with a shallow flux pool - raise shields and build excess flux while raked by the Gazer's graviton beam, or drop shields and open oneself to more direct attack.

Reception of the Gazer is as split: some commanders consider this an elegant weapon from a more civilized age, others, a design which compromises raw firepower for finicky guidance and targeting systems.

This pod-based autoloader allows more missiles to be delivered on-target over the course of a combat encounter, but requires a larger mount-point.

Anticipating two, even three, moves ahead in the strike and riposte of combat systems design, the Dragonfire was created to anticipate increasingly sophisticated anti-missile defense solutions. The concept is simple: use an enriched AM-catalyzed nuclear warhead to pump a focused plasma beam, delivering destructive energy without worry of point defense interception. The results were spectacular.

Implementation proved complex. Drawing upon Domain ONYX-rated physics research bloated the security bureaucracy of manufacture such that the project was deemed unprofitable. Domain bureaucracy is not a concern post-Collapse, of course.

The Dragonfire was created to anticipate increasingly sophisticated anti-missile defense solutions. The concept is simple: use an enriched AM-catalyzed nuclear warhead to pump a plasma beam, delivering energy without leaving an opening for PD interception. The results were spectacular.

Implementation proved complex. Drawing upon Domain ONYX-rated physics research bloated the security bureaucracy of manufacture such that the project was deemed unprofitable. Domain bureaucracy is not a concern post-Collapse, of course.

The Dragonfire pod is an enlarged version of the standard mount and loading system of the Dragonfire DEM, fit for large and lavishly outfitted warships.

The Hydra weapon system launches a clutch of semi-independently maneuverable DEM platforms from a single device. The submunitions maneuver to flank the primary shield of the target - assumed to be directed toward the threat of the attacker - and only then unleash beamfire.

The downsides of smaller payload and increased travel time - inviting point defense interception - are generally considered to be outweighed when the Hydra is combined with a suite of complementary weapon systems to overwhelm both the tactical flexibility and physical defenses of the targeted vessel.

A remnant of the autonomous AI fleets developed by the Tri-Tachyon Corporation. Illegal under Domain (and Hegemony) law, and an abomination to the Church of Galactic Redemption, the First AI War saw these creations purged from the Sector. So the official histories say.

Although operationalized in the Retribution design, the Orion Drive was never popular with crew or naval architects due to the great strain each jolt the propulsion system inflicted upon flesh and hardware. The Nova overcomes such limitations by dispensing with human crew altogether. The Orion Drive design thus freed from most burdensome constraints, every aspect could be upgraded to higher power levels using cutting-edge weapons technology and advanced solid-state Tri-Tachyon-designed components. The result is an AI-operated battlecruiser capable of fearsome speed and firepower.

A design dating to the first explosive expansion of the Domain, this gargantuan mass of armor and all-big-guns was the gauntleted fist that smashed all opposition, spreading hegemony by fear and force over all of spacefaring humanity that was worth conquering.

The steady march of military technology left the hull outdated, however. Its armor design was incompatible with early shield generators, its minimum crew complement staggering, and targeting systems unsophisticated. Modernized replacements were soon developed and the Onslaught-class, among others, was churned out by the great Domain forges. 

An age passed. And, as if by Providence, an expedition sent by the Knights of Ludd discovered an uncorrupted museum archive on a murdered world. A council of inquisitors weighed whether to destroy the Domain-era knowledge, holding a fiery - and secret - debate over the line between sin and virtue, between righteous craft and corrupting technology. An unusually open-minded senior knight-inquisitor examined the contents in detail and persuaded the council to defer the destruction order indefinitely. 

This hull was christened "Invictus", a testament to the impossibly heavy armor and vast mass of this absurd cathedral of war. No proper navy would field this monstrosity, but the Church and its Knights can count on a bounty of faithful volunteer-militants to crew the huge munition feeders and crude targeting stations.

An ancient but unvenerated class, the Retribution is an extreme battlecruiser design which dates to the renaissance of military experimentation during the first consolidation period of the Domain. It sacrifices armor for firepower and tremendous speed for its size class via a nearly unique implementation of "Orion Drive" technology which was considered an archaic curiosity even then.

The physical stress inflicted upon both human flesh and ship components by the propulsive jolts made the Retribution an unpopular ship in the Domain Armada, one of few opinions shared whole-heartedly by crew and officers alike. Only a handful of examples were ever deployed by the Armada proper, the Retribution finding more use among frontier mercenaries and pirate-hunters that relied upon unexpected bursts of speed and hyper-aggressive tactics.

The Pegasus was an aspirational design initiative by Altair Exotech building off the immense profit and prestige generated by the "Cruiser School" turn of the Domain Armada procurement arm. Orion Shipyards, the primary supplier of capital craft to the Armada, naturally considered this an imposition on a field it had dominated up to that point. Many of the old admirals agreed and uptake was slow; nevertheless, the Pegasus anchored several of the newer battlegroups and found favor among a generation of young officers.

The unparalleled heavy missile-focused loadout is a striking distinction from more traditional designs, allowing the Pegasus to compromise on scale of power systems and flux-handling while maintaining respectable armor, top speed, and maneuverability. Traditionalists criticize the Pegasus' "staying power" under fire while counter-critics respond that if a fleet finds itself under sustained heavy fire, it has already made a serious tactical error. Despite the debates (which continue to this day) the combat performance of the Pegasus-class has earned it begrudging respect even from detractors.

The Executor is a modification of Altair Exotech's radical "Cruiser School" capital Pegasus-class hull. Modifying starships at the forge-level is a feat only available to polities willing to invest in employing a highly trained specialist class of engineer-technicians. After all, why invest in risky innovations when the bones of the Domain provide ships to fill every role? -- Because the Lion of Askonia demands it! And, through domination of the starship fuel economy, Supreme Executor Philip Andrada had the credits to pay for a capital ship specially designed to outfit the products of his extravagant energy weapon program.

Although the official reports have been subtly improved by parties seeking to avoid punishment, the Executor-class outfitted to Diktat specs tends to slightly underperform the grand expectations set out by the original proposal. But none could argue that the project was not delivered on schedule, and that its results don't make for a fine and terrifying sight in the skies of the Askonia system.

An ill-fated design from the start, the Grendel was originally planned as a heavy phase droneship. Casualties would be irrelevant and routine damage anticipated, for this ship is a brawler which can phase-shift through a first wave of hostile ordnance to appear in the midst of the enemy battle line ready to unleash missiles and heavy firepower. The trick is, of course, performing this maneuver safely by carefully juggling flux-load and positioning, though its service record demonstrates that nothing is particularly safe about the Grendel.  

The brainchild of an eccentric admiral who managed to capture procurement authority over an entire frontier sector, the first prototypes were installed with low-level AI core commanders. The AIs became rapidly unstable, even erratic, after only a handful of phase shifts. Subsequently, the precise details of these experiments were suppressed by an obscure intelligence ministry of the Domain and the project saved only by the admiral's personal intervention. With AI unsuitable, the next best disposable resource was tapped, and the Grendel saw its first combat service on the far fringes crewed almost entirely by Domain Armada penal battalions.
AI Core Cradle
descriptions.text2:
The AI administrator control bunker was secured from the threat contained within as well as the multitude of threat vectors without.

Above all the entire operation was kept absolutely secret; a handsomely compensated human actor was hired to perform as the 'face' for the AI core's decision-making.

descriptions.text1: Hound in the Hangar
descriptions.text2:
A rust-bucket Hound came in last shift. Cargo of low-grade ore. I crewed with a Hound 20 cycles ago, I know the logs don't add up - their last run wouldn't have even paid for the fuel. And I know where the shielded holds are. Broke my heart how young the cap was though, a poor kid out of Mozzy. Just like I was. If I bust 'em, I kill their one chance to get out. So I didn't.

Delete log entry.
descriptions.text3: unlocked

descriptions.text1: Cargo Loading
descriptions.text2:
"All the big contracts go to the toadies kneeling at the feet of the high-and-mighty. Call them approved vendors, Gens-clients, logistical auxilliaries, Faithful traders. It's all the same."

"It's about us outsiders being kept out, pushed into smuggling and black markets, squeezed by patrols on one side, pirates on the other."
descriptions.text4: - patron, anonymous, overheard at 'The Fusion Torch'

descriptions.text1: Space Wreckage
descriptions.text2:
"Is there no place left unmarked by the leavings of Moloch, fouled by skin of plastic, and bones of alloy, and scales of ceramic?"

"Is there no place left which may be made sacred and given unto the glory of the Creator alone?"

descriptions.text1: Vacuum Colony
descriptions.text2: Purposeful habitation of barren worlds has been long considered one of the signs of true civilization alongside interstellar travel and fusion of the atom. A being confined to its gravity well might as well be an infant in the cradle, a mere animal without awareness or control over its destiny.
descriptions.text3: unlocked
descriptions.text4: - Academician Florian Proxima, Domain History department, Galatia Academy

descriptions.text1: Hull Breach
descriptions.text2: The flaw went back to the forging. An error, a misalignment in the pseudocrystal, a mistake that spiralled outward - just enough. A standard quality control scan would have seen it, but it'd be tagged low-risk. It was a hundred cycles of hard use, sharp maneuvers, the hasty repairs, the delayed inspections, the lost records that made the compartment a death-trap.
descriptions.text3: unlocked

descriptions.text1: Jump-point, to Hyperspace
descriptions.text2:
There are places where a balance is found between the dance of celestial bodies, some mingling of qualities ineffable to all but those absolutely devoted to esoteric physics.

It is there we pierce the veil into the great and stormy sea beyond the stars.

descriptions.text1: Jump-point, from Hyperspace
descriptions.text2:
Now our contracts up, holds full and ready /
Hoo-rah for we jump now t'ward the core /
We'll burn bright, bright long and steady

descriptions.text1: Jump-point, Wormhole
descriptions.text2:
Go in there not knowing exactly where you're coming out?

That's how you end up a bit of glitter indistinguishable from cosmic background radiation.

descriptions.text1: City From Above
descriptions.text2: "He risked the entire Galatia system, hundreds of thousands of citizens. That might be just one subsector of a metroplex down there," he waved vaguely in the direction of Chicomoztoc. "But," his voice hardened, "I will not allow any 'grand experiments' that endanger these people."
descriptions.text3: unlocked

descriptions.text1: Desert Moon Ruins
descriptions.text2: An ancient sporeship encountered Cibola in a cooler and wetter age than its equilibrium, placing it within the ship's colonization parameters. Later Domain explorers found a dying world populated by a small, backward, and desperate civilization clinging to survival.

descriptions.text1: Quartermaster
descriptions.text2: "You think the inertial dampers will protect you during a combat maneuver? If it isn't stowed, it's a missile primed to core you and the next three crew coming up the access shaft. I want this shameful display cleaned up before the end of the shift."
descriptions.text3: unlocked

descriptions.text1: Communications Relay
descriptions.text2: This communication platform used long lost Domain-era technology yet remained essential to civilized life in the Persean Sector. The rapidly pulsing hyperwaves suitable for FTL data transmission have been shown to damage DNA so these relays were always stationed well away from habitats.

descriptions.text1: Abandoned Station 1
descriptions.text2:
The colonization program dictated construction around key gravity wells of orbital infrastructure which included repair docks, industrial nanoforges, comms hubs, terraforming depots, armories, research laboratories, and habitation for defrosted cryosleepers.

Much remains. More still is as broken and dead as the Human Domain's avaricious dreams.
descriptions.text3: unlocked

descriptions.text1: Abandoned Station 2
descriptions.text2: "There's ghosties in the old orbitals- don't you laugh, dirt-boot. It's true. I've seen 'em... or less seen 'em than felt 'em. They got signs. Static on the comms when you're in deep. Valves that come loose when you're not a-lookin'. Tools that hain't where you secured 'em. Great tombs they are, and properly ought be left sleepin' cold."

descriptions.text1: Abandoned Station
descriptions.text2:
Most abandoned stations were plundered long ago. What remains are the stripped foundations of a fallen empire; twisted spars, cracked agrav plates, shattered machines, and seams thermal-cycled to ruin.

A few smugglers and black-market traders use the long, quiet orbit of these stations for drop-points. A dozen corpses and cored shuttle are the not uncommon tell of a deal gone bad.

descriptions.text1: Jangala Station
descriptions.text2: Orbiting megacity, naval yard, and port; the axis of Corvus, swarmed by Starship traffic. Ancient repair gantries skulked between corroded industrial hangars in the shadow of laboratory rings and support modules. Higher still, commercial bays and metroplex districts were shepherded by the C&C spire bristling with weapons pods.

descriptions.text1: Industrial Megafacility
descriptions.text2: Heavy industrial manufacturing relied on great nanoforges recovered from the ruins of the Domain. However their output quality decayed over cycles; nanoscale corruption led to growing macroscopic flaws. Much of the output had to be repaired by cruder methods, and much was scrapped and fed back as the refined feedstock for which the aging forges ever hungered.

descriptions.text1: Terran Orbit
descriptions.text2:
The Eridani-Utopia Terraforming Corporation specs provide the most widely accepted "terran" baseline for the allegedly ideal human environment.

The many deviations of natural planetary environments from the specifications may be corrected through technological intervention including ice-asteroid bombardment, orbital burns, biomodded ecosystems, orbital megastructures, and other methods provided by the EUT.
descriptions.text3: unlocked

descriptions.text1: Pirate Station
descriptions.text2:
"Chaos? No sir, what it is, is honesty. Here, if a man wants you dead, you'll see it in his eyes 'fore he makes a move. Better that than a computer in some off-world office deciding your air supply isn't worth maintaining."

Sadly my guide was found dead the next shift. Shot in the back, ironically.

descriptions.text1: Metroplex 00
descriptions.text2: Statistical sampling suggests that a significant percent of all economic activity in the Sector is 'off the books', and a significant portion of that goes toward 'pirates' and so-called 'decivilized' populations, to say nothing of the undocumented populations within the Core itself. The census of the Persean Sector could be off by as much as an order of magnitude. Imagine!
descriptions.text3: unlocked

descriptions.text1: Metroplex 01
descriptions.text2: The people of Chicomoztoc, the majority population of the Persean Sector, lived in vast underground arcologies blasted into the sleeping crust of their world. This cluster of conjoined hive-cities were ruled as often by powerful demagogues promising reform and employment as by technocrat-criminal patronage networks distributing spoils to their supporters -- and influence to whoever was paying them off.
descriptions.text3: unlocked

descriptions.text1: Kay-arco
descriptions.text2: Cyclopean arcology substructure flashed by the windows of the primary ring tube toward a far segment of the metroplex. A smaller passenger lift filled with the smell of sweat and machine oil as a shift of undersea laborers returned home. Glimpses of the towering arms of Kay-arco appeared for short seconds, glittering with thousands of windows, before being again darkened by a blur of mildewed plating.
descriptions.text3: unlocked

descriptions.text1: Hive City
descriptions.text2: The hives of Chicomoztoc were occasionally locked down by riots, protest, or insurrection. But so long as the great Forges kept churning out starships, machinery, and goods, the Hegemony meddled only lightly in that great underworld of humanity.

descriptions.text1: Orbital Station
descriptions.text2:
Enormous orbital stations hosted shipyards, habitats, factories, and stockpiles of weapons and supplies.

These platforms allowed what remained of humanity to organize interstellar polities and project military and commercial power across the Persean Sector.

descriptions.text1: Mine
descriptions.text2:
"It's a story as old as time. We gotta get what's good down in there up and out where it can go off somewhere else to make someone else rich."

"Miserable work, it's true, but there's ways of coping."

descriptions.text1: Ruins of Mairaath
descriptions.text2:
Nightmarish storms circled the globe, stirring the ashes of a murdered world.

Even after the apocalyptic ruin of Mairaath humanity still huddled in the broken shells of great cities brought low, blasted by unending wind.

descriptions.text1: Eochu Bres, Xanadu
descriptions.text2: Shining Tri-Tachyon Corporation arcologies towered over a riotous sprawl of shantytown conurbation. Company salariat were born, lived, and died protected by security drones in the high city Xanadu while a desperate class of immiserated laborers dwelled in the low city where anything at all was bought or sold.

descriptions.text1: Eochu Bres, Skyarco II
descriptions.text2:
Gleaming monoliths glittered, spears of capital upthrust through the glowering flesh of the world. Skyarco II loomed prismatic.

The shuttle alit on a landing pad held at some distance from the facade by an airy support rib. It looked impossibly thin, but after touch down felt solid as a mountain.

descriptions.text1: Planetary Survey
descriptions.text2:
The fringe of the Persean Second is filled with worlds lost, forgotten, and never seen at all by consciousness born of flesh.

There are green fields of toxic xenolife, tombs frosted with nitrogen snow, roiling cauldrons of magma and brimstone, and planets made of living storm; vast fortunes to be uncovered, barbarian-worlds incapable of starflight, and the weapons of ancient wars primed to attack any interloper.
descriptions.text3: unlocked

descriptions.text1: Luddic Shrine
descriptions.text2:
Pilgrims were offered tea, water, and ritual washing. The air was filled with sweat and incense. All around, a river of faith and ritual flowed.
In the hardship of life in the Persean Sector, as in the hardship of the pilgrimage, the Faithful found a kind of peace and meaning in the vacuum left by the Collapse.

descriptions.text1: Orbital Construction
descriptions.text2: The ceramoid plating slowly peeled away in an aeon-long cascading fail state. Metallic ribs exposed, bleached by stellar winds, charged and released the pulsing dance of magnetic fields, the thrumming of orbits and the gnawing sirocco of micrometeorites.

descriptions.text1: Dead Gate
descriptions.text2: "Humanity was thence scattered abroad upon the face of the galaxy, speaking one tongue, united by the demon Gates in one body of worldly law. But we had forgotten the laws of God, mightier than any fusion lance! God would remind humanity of its place in this universe."

descriptions.text1: Active Gate
descriptions.text2:
It is a humming ring of adamantine material. If one knows how to look, sensors can detect their faint vibration in higher dimensions.

It is like a barely heard song, a door waiting to be opened.

descriptions.text1: Eventide
descriptions.text2: Leading families of Eventide sponsored the stellar mirrors and shades to maintain islands of comfortable habitability. The disgraced and poor, meanwhile, lived in the twilight peripheries where harsh climactic shifts of the slow summer-day/winter-night cycle had to be endured in full force.

descriptions.text1: Volturn, Ocean World
descriptions.text2: The port of Volturn was built on a loose flotilla of huge, singed-looking barges that wallowed in an oily sea. Offloading spacers are interrogated by dour security officers, then allowed into the traders' concourse. Merchants in dull suits, loyalty pins dutifully displayed on the collar, passed around a datapad loaded with incoming cargo manifests.

descriptions.text1: Spacer Bar
descriptions.text2: The spacer bar was filled by the human white-noise of conversation and revelry. Ad-holos buzzed softly from ceiling-mounted projectors, shining garish highlights through glasses and bottles as crews mingled with merchants and locals trading drink for rumors, jobs, and connections.

descriptions.text1: Pirate Bar
descriptions.text2:
"Ya hear that? Salazar's crew, they think we're cowardly dirt-eaters."
[shouting, booing]
"I say, I say they're wrong! I say we go out there and show 'em which way the Reaper flies! Who's with me?"
[cheering, stomping, breaking glass]

descriptions.text1: Stellar Mirror
descriptions.text2: Ultra-light orbital mirror arrays which reflect and concentrate stellar energy were a common terraforming tool. The art of their use was brought to apogee by the Eridani-Utopia Terraforming Corporation during the height of the Domain's expansion.

descriptions.text1: Stellar Shade
descriptions.text2: Judicious placement of stellar shades and mirrors in orbit of Eventide allowed for ideal conditions in large pockets of the carefully maintained territory. The majority of the population was settled in leased urban cantons built in arcs and rings of the penumbrae surrounding the vast, bright aristocratic estate-plantations.

descriptions.text1: Hegemony Spacer Bar
descriptions.text2: A row of taps adorned the wall under bottles from every one of the Core Worlds - and a few from elsewhere. Merchant-captains mingled with off-duty officers at the bar, served by uniformed staff. In one corner a pack of navy cadets shouted and sang, desperate to enjoy their last shift of freedom.

descriptions.text1: Sindria
descriptions.text2: The hive-cities never recovered from the influx of refugees due to the Askonia Crisis. Andrada channelled resources toward the military and its supporting industries instead. A desperate underclass would grow beneath the boots of those lucky and loyal enough to have found positions in the bureaucracy or miltech establishment.

descriptions.text1: Sindrian Diktat Spacer Bar
descriptions.text2: The dark entry left behind the noisome propaganda broadcasts of the throughway. Off-duty laborers drank away their ration credits at benches set beneath Diktat insignia. In one corner a cadre of finely dressed officer-bureaucrats called for a round. And even here a framed holo of the Lion of Sindria surveyed the ceiling, forever aloof.

descriptions.text1: Tri-Tachyon Spacer Bar
descriptions.text2: The lounge was adorned in gilt geometrics. Columns underlit by cool light-tubes hung in the air. Slick careerists and wannabes in crisp suits negotiated deals while buying increasingly unlikely cocktails. A few spacers engaged in subdued drinking in the low seats, glancing uneasily at what was either abstract art or a holo-projection rig looming from the ceiling.

descriptions.text1: Gilead
descriptions.text2:
The face of Gilead smiled behind clouds of purest silk, cerulean seas, and verdant continents of gentle, rolling wilderness.

The Church reigned as a stern gardener, ensuring piety and duty in honoring the ground upon which Ludd once trod.

descriptions.text1: Shrine of Jangala
descriptions.text2: There were figures, like an overgrown statue garden. The forms blistered with growth, draped in tendrils heavy with fruiting bodies. One moved. Not the wind, but a pilgrim exposed without a haz-suit. And there were others, wearing only light robes amongst the inimical xenolife. Easily overtaken.

descriptions.text1: Hesperus
descriptions.text2:
Monasteries clung to the sublime promontories which ringed the volcanic provinces forced through world-wrapping ice. Unseen were the bunkers, heavy batteries, and missile silos of the Knights of Ludd.

The reigning Presbyter Orbis declared a handful of special economic zones on the shifting floes; these transmitted welcomes, their beacons calling outside traders to port.

descriptions.text1: Shrine of Hesperus
descriptions.text2: The floor was a welded field of armored plates weathered into intricate patterns by the varied atmospheres of worlds on which the Knights of Ludd fought and died. The niches held empty helmets like so many skulls.

descriptions.text1: Shrine of Killa
descriptions.text2:
There were empty sockets, rib-cages, femurs and spines set in recesses, built into columns, covering every surface. The dust came from the crumbling bodies, the bones.

Like a veil, it flexed slowly in the electrostatic field strong enough to overcome the low gravity of the world to hang in near-vacuum.

descriptions.text1: Shrine of Volturn
descriptions.text2: It was filled with guns, explosives, grenades, cellmags. Crates and racks piled high. The shrine itself was set under a round viewport holding back a titanic mass of water. A few candles struggled to maintain even a decent flicker among the ranks of their dead comrades.

descriptions.text1: Shrine of Volturn, fake
descriptions.text2:
It was a sad thing set in the back of a back room, rows of candles arrayed around the wooden centerpiece carved with images of Ludd's travails. The candles were dead, the shrine illuminated only by grimy portholes.

"We do not have many visitors, you see," the curate said.

descriptions.text1: Protest
descriptions.text2: The steady advance of gendarmerie broke the protest line, shock-prods rose and fell to muffled shouts and silent screaming. Drones, flashing laser-light, deployed restraint foam on struggling forms. Fists, signs, and hand tools were useless against the power-armored officers.

descriptions.text1: Preparation for Raid
descriptions.text2: Each squad prepared as if for surgery, cool and precise. Hell was set to pour forth once the breaching charges blasted through access-points, into churning storms of dust and debris and fire strobing with weapon discharge.

descriptions.text1: Raid for Valuables
descriptions.text2: Dull thuds, nearly subsonic, were felt through the armored mass. Breaching charges. When the marines finally broke the vault proper, it was with overwhelming force of sound and light. No unsuited human could withstand the assault on the senses. They were blinded, in shock.

descriptions.text1: Disruption Raid
descriptions.text2: The raid pivoted on mere minutes of chaos. Comms across the hemisphere crackled with static; only tightbeam relays could pierce the rain of EM scatter amid clouds of chaff and disruption. Casualty reports rolled in, displays on the bridge bleeding to fill the volume with a bloody glow.

descriptions.text1: Covert Raid
descriptions.text2: The marine squads withdrew, leaving broken bulkheads and blaring alarms amid the sporadic return-fire. The MUNISEC were still mobilizing to lock down the port when the last raider shuttle lifted. Its jets kicked up dust that mixed with the leaking atmo.

descriptions.text1: Kazeron
descriptions.text2: Kazeron was rich in exotic metals, the former core of a gas giant blasted away in an ancient celestial catastrophe. Its industrial base, built to feed the Domain's Persean frontier heavy machinery and terraforming plant, was quickly adapted to build a warfleet which gave pause to the XIVth Battlegroup.

descriptions.text1: Fikenhild
descriptions.text2: The small ocean-moon of Fikenhild was the political center of the system, seat of the King and representative to the Persean League. The great floating arcologies glittered night and day, homes to the highly esteemed holo-entertainment studios of Westernesse.

descriptions.text1: Ilm
descriptions.text2: More than a company town, Ilm was a company world, from the orbital security platforms shining above to the teleoperated mines ripped deep down into the crust. Ruled by a semi-militarized corporate board, the identity of investors was not public information, though the least paranoid speculation favored a mix of League and Tri-Tachyon capital.

descriptions.text1: Luddic Teahouse
descriptions.text2: A vice squad brute stared down all who entered. They could shut the place down at any time, but the teahouse-speakeasy provided a conduit with the commerce required for holy war. Inside was dim and crowded; the stench of drug fumes and cheap liquor competed with a disdain for modern enzyme soap.

descriptions.text1: Mazalot
descriptions.text2:
They led you through a town of plastered brick and corroded salvage. Bright paint and lush gardens managed, just, to stave off a sense of decay.

Before long you stood before large doors of etched metal. The militants were met by another pair, similarly armed. The most senior lowered his mask.

descriptions.text1: Chalcedon
descriptions.text2:
Chalcedonian architecture trended toward cyclopeanism on the surface. Below, protected from the storms, were the same cheap prefabs seen on poor worlds across the Sector.

The rain sent nasty rivulets of fluid slithering down conduits to pool on moldy canopies. The sky's feeble light diffused into a flattening murk.

descriptions.text1: Sentinel, the lost colony
descriptions.text2: There was a cluster of neat, low structures; earthworks and hull panels spotted with forgeglass, sprouting vents. The streets were clean and the citizenry uniformed by job role. Despite fixing outsiders with open stares, they did not falter in their assignments.

descriptions.text1: Sentinel, the found colony
descriptions.text2:
It cannot be said to thrive, but the colony of Sentinel gained a new sense of hope and energy after reintegration with the Hegemony.

The citizens were diligent, orderly, and disciplined. It was thought that they would make good officer candidates despite quiet objections from Eventide's old guard.

descriptions.text1: Gate Hauler discovery
descriptions.text2:
A Leviathan from out of time, familiar at once from its depictions in the post-Domain Persean Sector. The magisterial force hushes and humbles officers and crew. It makes them reverent, as if they found themselves before the corpse of a thunderous, cruel god who once ruled the skies.

To awaken it, to touch the divine, must fall somewhere between sacrilege and sanctification.

descriptions.text1: Gate Hauler in flight
descriptions.text2: These were the massive, automated starships which bore the Gates that established near-instantaneous connections between distant stars. After a journey of countless lonely cycles, the Gate would be emplaced in a new system and activated, thence to disgorge an explosion of newcomers seeking resources, data, and experiences to feed the grand economy and culture of the Human Domain.
descriptions.text3: unlocked

descriptions.text1: Prepare for Bombardment
descriptions.text2: "If it's just followin' orders, it's not me that's going against the convention. Then it's on the captain. Right?"

descriptions.text1: Tactical Bombardment
descriptions.text2:
A spatter of hollowed icons represented dead targets across the display. The last one, full and red, blinked out into a scabrous brown.

A subtle gesture collapsed the image and the icons winked out as one. The holomatrix snowed, then reformed into nav mode, the fleet holding station in low orbit.

descriptions.text1: Saturation Bombardment
descriptions.text2:
When Loke came from the Abyss /
The first world, he burned /
The second, he took without a shot /
The third- look out, there he is!

descriptions.text1: Missed Crew Payment
descriptions.text2: "The contract can suck vacuum. No credits, no crew."

descriptions.text1: Nav Buoy
descriptions.text2: A navigation buoy dating to the Domain era monitored local system hyperfield topography. The telemetry was of great use to configure and tune fleet drive bubbles.

descriptions.text1: Free Orbit
descriptions.text2:
I asked what drew him back out there, time and time again. The old spacer took a long time before he answered.

"Because it's clean," he said.

descriptions.text1: Sensor Array
descriptions.text2: The Domain-era array could passively monitor an entire star system and had a transmitter capable of encrypted real-time FTL data transmission to friendly fleets. The telemetry would supplement fleet-based sensors, effectively increasing their power and range.

descriptions.text1: Sensor Array, Makeshift
descriptions.text2: Makeshift sensor arrays built using post-Collapse technology passively monitored entire star systems. An on-board transmitter was capable of encrypted real-time, FTL data transmission to friendly fleets. This telemetry would supplement fleet-based sensors, effectively increasing their power and range.

descriptions.text1: Galatia Academy
descriptions.text2: The Galatia Academy is the most prestigious university in the Persean Sector. The office of provost directs teaching and research and draws upon alumni to influence new generations of the brightest - or richest - students.

descriptions.text1: Fusion Lamp
descriptions.text2: "Don't be too impressed, walker. It's a dim imitation of God's first day."

descriptions.text1: Salvors in the Ruins
descriptions.text2:
It appeared empty at first. A colossal tomb, never filled.

Drone-mounted radar drew a ghostly schematic while suit lights piled beams into the echoing volume, catching drifts of dust and gas set aloft by the opening. Cables gleamed in the dark, snaking along the long ranks of coffers.

descriptions.text1: Derelict Exploration
descriptions.text2: "It is said that an ex-salvor is either old or rich, never both."

descriptions.text1: Zero-G Dead
descriptions.text2:
"It's finding the pieces that's the worst. Not so much out there, frozen or fried, but those bits that stick on 'til you're back inside."

"Doesn't smell much at first but after a few shifts you need to run a mil-grade dehaz on all your kit. Can't stand it."

descriptions.text1: Large Cache
descriptions.text2:
A huge structure loomed, the monolithic facets of its hull scarred by countless cycles of space weathering. The hangars were large enough to hide a vast store of valuable commodities.
Or, perhaps, a fleet of moderate size.

descriptions.text1: Tartessus, the Cathedral of Holy Exodus
descriptions.text2:
You stood together at last in the plaza under the archway of the Cathedral of Holy Exodus.

"And it is the seat of not more than a few heretical notions of doctrine, I'm afraid," he said in a low voice.

descriptions.text1: Cathedral of Holy Exodus
descriptions.text2:
Among towering columns were affixed recovered landing pods of the early Luddic refugee ships, now integrated into the vaults, painted with gilt and green, bedecked with candles and hanging glass ornaments which broke the beams of the sun - filtered through ranks of high windows - into thousands of rainbow shards endlessly refracting.

It was an ecstasy of light, a galaxy unto itself.

descriptions.text1: Abyssal Light
descriptions.text2: A cold light filled the viewscreen, stark against the utter darkness of the hyperspace abyss. It seemed to pulse, shifting dimmer and then brighter, following no discernable pattern. It did not flicker like a flame, nor like a failing comms signal, but like something flitting at the very edge of consciousness...

descriptions.text1: Abyssal Light Encounter
descriptions.text2:
Cold light began to grow in the primary display. A subtle pulse begged for attention.

A call of alarm, a flare of red, and a pause as the bridge officers took in the eruption of alerts that spilled across their display interfaces.

descriptions.text1: Exotic Weapon Assembly
descriptions.text2: Haz-suited technicians tended the containment machinery, stepping over coils of tube and wire. A mess of makeshift components were pulled from the common microforge libraries then torn apart and re-engineered to operate in this unusual, even extraordinary, application.

descriptions.text1: Cargo Pods
descriptions.text2:
Often filled with recoverable goods, even operational cryopods, a clutch of cargo pods in open space are a tempting target to scavengers. 

Trade convoys fleeing pirates sometimes dump cargo in the hope that their pursuers will power down their engines and content themselves with easy plunder.

descriptions.text1: Coronal Tap, Interior
descriptions.text2: These megastructures once powered the unfathomable industrial might of the Domain, putting the human civilization well toward Kardashev type II status. It is capable of extracting energy on an astronomical scale directly from the linked star.

descriptions.text1: Coronal Tap, Exterior
descriptions.text2: These megastructures once powered the unfathomable industrial might of the Domain, putting the human civilization well toward Kardashev type II status. It is capable of extracting energy on an astronomical scale directly from the linked star.

descriptions.text1: Cryosleeper
descriptions.text2: "Those who awake from cryosleep who were laid to rest in the time of the Domain are perhaps the most lost of all. Many, though not all, imagined they would populate the far end of a rich frontier; they accepted that they would leave behind all they once knew. Now they all find themselves cut loose from all reference, unmoored in history."

descriptions.text1: Uncrewed Probe
descriptions.text2: It was a common class of probe used for research, surveying, and surveillance, the sort of hardware used by civilian enterprise and research institutions. Often run without an active transponder so as not to invite opportunistic scavengers, an active ping will return the ID-packet required both under interfactional commerce law and by most credible insurance combines.

descriptions.text1: A heavy ballistics and medium missile firepower-focused station module which effortlessly vaporizes smaller ships while giving cruisers and capitals good reason to maintain their distance. This well-armored and robustly engineered structure is designed to maximize compatibility with the low-fidelity construction typical of frontier nanoforge output.

A station module designed for close-volume power projection via two space fighter wings hangars and associated support facilities. Defended by respectable ballistics and medium missile firepower, this is a well-armored and robustly engineered structure designed to maximize compatibility with the low-fidelity construction typical of frontier nanoforge output.

Heavy battlestation armor is assembled in various forms from modular pieces to fit site-specific requirements. The primary structure, pierced only under conditions of heavy bombardment, consists of a custom semi-flexible high-tensile lattice filled with ultrahard nanoforged ceramic-metal composite blocks. Over this are placed alternating layers of foamed metal and 'wrap' consisting of many layers of sacrificial/reflective ablation skin.

This unit demonstrates the classic chevron arrangement.

Heavy battlestation armor is assembled in various forms from modular pieces to fit site-specific requirements. The primary structure, pierced only under conditions of heavy bombardment, consists of a custom semi-flexible high-tensile lattice filled with ultrahard nanoforged ceramic-metal composite blocks. Over this are placed alternating layers of foamed metal and 'wrap' consisting of many layers of sacrificial/reflective ablation skin.

This unit is an enlarged chevron arrangement.

Point-defense bastions, usually mounted on large booms extended from the primary volume of the station, enhance defenses against strike-craft, missiles, and frigates. This well-armored and robustly engineered structure is designed to maximize compatibility with the low-fidelity construction typical of frontier nanoforge output.

A heavy ballistics-focused citadel which mounts a broadside equivalent to a heavy battleship and its own self-contained flux grid. Usually placed on a spar extending from the primary volume of the station to provide overlapping fields of fire and, in the event of catastrophe, to minimize damage to the parent station. This well-armored and robustly engineered structure is designed to maximize compatibility with the low-fidelity construction typical of frontier nanoforge output.

An armored spar used to protect the flank of a station's primary batteries, this defense element is constructed of modular nanoforged components mounted on a tough yet relatively flexible structural lattice. Station armor is designed to find an ideal compromise between hardness, deflection, impact absorption, and heat dispersion across a wide range of combat scenarios, and as a rule permits for more generous mass allowance than could be reasonably mounted on a starship.

A very heavy station defense broadside module, this component alone demonstrates firepower comparable to any two standard line battleships. The combined mounting station segment - including this and counterweight defense and armor modules - is generally operated at a higher than usual rate of rotation to permit rapid on-target/recovery cycle.

A fighter support station module designed to enhance a station's local volume power-projection by mounting multiple fighter bays and missile launch points. This is a relatively soft target which nonetheless includes respectable point defense and armored hangars. A munitions depot, specialized on-site forges, and an isolated combat power system are situated on the inward-face.

A missile support bastion may be mounted on larger battlestations and star fortresses to enhance defense. This unit is designed to support other, direct firepower-focused modules by maintaining pressure and exploiting missile strike opportunities. A respectable point defense array discourages strike fighters while heavy armor allows for uninterrupted operation under heavy bombardment.

A dedicated advanced shield module designed to work as a specialized component in a whole-station defense matrix. Specialized shield modules with their own isolated combat reactors and flux grids allow firepower modules to vent without dropping defenses. This module is always paired and mounted on a rotating chassis so that station shields may alternate venting hard flux, theoretically creating an impenetrable defense.

An advanced armored spur which takes advantage of sophisticated nanoforge techniques. The plating of this module exploits unusual properties of quasicrystals and a 3D nanotubule mesh. This high-tech material science allows for armor-equivalent at lower mass and volume but the advantages are somewhat offset by the finicky manufacture and assembly process; specialist technicians are required to build this module and re-integrate replacement components after taking battle damage.

An advanced hangar module which may field four wings of fightercraft to dominate near-volume combat encounters. Due to a philosophy of specialization, this module does not have its own shield module; it is designed to work within the whole-station defense matrix. Nevertheless, enough directed energy firepower is mounted to discourage lighter warships. Integrates a fighter recall device, a specialized system originally created for the Astral-class carrier.

An advanced energy weapons battery, this specialized station defense module provides long-range firepower. Due to the whole-station defense matrix philosophy of design, no shield emitter is included; this means that the isolated combat reactors and flux grid can be dedicated entirely to offensive weapon systems.

A huge lunette designed to fill certain gaps discovered in the practical application of the whole-station defense matrix philosophy. The advanced plating requires sophisticated nanoforge production techniques which exploit unusual properties of quasicrystals and a 3D nanotubule mesh. This high-tech material science allows for equivalent armor protection at lower mass and volume than alternatives but the advantage is somewhat offset by the finicky manufacture and assembly process; specialist technicians are required to build this module and re-integrate replacement components after taking battle damage.

An advanced citadel possessing powerful shields, advanced armor, and bristling with energy weapons. This module was designed to fill certain gaps in the practical application of the specialized-module whole-station defense matrix philosophy. Because it extends beyond the coverage of dedicated shield modules, its own shield generator is an adaptation of the fortress shield system mounted on the Paragon-class battleship.

A small armored module which mounts a pair of small turrets usually used for asteroid defense and mining. It has no shield emitter, but this unit does possess a dedicated power-flux subsystem so that its mothership is not left defenseless in the case of emergency power failure.

An armored engine pod with its own power-flux subsystem and a small complement of mining and impactor defense turrets. Built to ensure that the mothership may operate even under the most hostile conditions across countless cycles.
A small gun-pod with its own backup reactor and flux grid. The turrets are generally dedicated to impactor defense.
A gun-pod which usually mounts a medium-class mining blaster so that the mothership can more efficiently harvest material necessary to produce additional exploration probes.

A gun-pod with a light complement of anti-impactor weapons and, usually, a medium-class mining blaster so that the mothership can more efficiently harvest material to produce additional exploration probes.

An exploration mothership bow sensor mast which mounts a respectable suite of anti-impactor turrets as well as a mining blaster to assist in material harvesting in support of the long-term mission of long-range survey. Firepower is light and mostly utilitarian, though it will discourage casual pirate-scavengers.
An armor module featuring high-tech nanoforged material technology. Seamless integration of peculiarly aesthetic macro-to-nanoscale fractal quasicrystal morphology suggests AI design.

A projecting advanced weapons platform of AI design. No internal life-support volumes; open-vacuum access tubes for maintenance drones are too small for human technicians. Features seamless integration of peculiarly aesthetic macro-to-nanoscale fractal quasicrystal morphology.

An advanced, AI-designed defense module utilizing a powerful shield and mounting dual Paladin PD turrets which will tear apart missiles and fighters alike with inhuman efficiency. Features seamless integration of peculiarly aesthetic macro-to-nanoscale fractal quasicrystal morphology.

An advanced, AI-designed support fighter hangar. Internal fighter repair and maintenance volumes are kept in near-vacuum and optimized to inhuman levels of efficiency due to lack of life support and safety requirements. PD coverage is modest; defensive turrets discourage strike fighters and opportunistic frigates. Armor features seamless integration of peculiarly aesthetic macro-to-nanoscale fractal quasicrystal morphology.

An advanced, AI-design firepower support weapon platform. Features dedicated combat generators and independent flux grid capable of powering primary large energy weapon battery and secondary medium-class energy turrets. Lack of life support requirements or habitable internal volumes enhances combat efficiency. Armor features seamless integration of peculiarly aesthetic macro-to-nanoscale fractal quasicrystal morphology.
A starship-sized structure of regular angular, geometric forms, albeit battle-damaged. It appears to consist largely of ferric alloys and has no active internal power source.

A rare, experimental prototype developed by the Tri-Tachyon Corporation, the Anubis-class hull has nearly full arc-coverage from three large energy turrets integrated into a controversial new flux grid. This 'new paradigm of flux management' is said to be directly interfaced with temporal manipulation technology of unknown provenance. Additional armament includes front-facing universal hardpoints and a fighter bay. The Anubis was unable to fulfill a robust multi-role tactical function due to poor flux performance so it is usually relegated to escort functions where, surprisingly, it excels.

The Anubis Project steering committee, keen to win support from as many departments as possible, drew upon new applications seeking customer validation from an exceptionally wide range of Tri-Tachyon's suite of breakthrough technologies. The project was then split into parallel operations at a handful of company black-sites to maximize security (and minimize oversight), leading to certain understandable late-stage compromises. It was hoped that the multi-functional product would cover more user-segments than one with more limited focus through a rough roll-out period. Then widespread field testing would surely enable rapid iteration which would lead, ultimately, to product maturity well ahead of conventional timelines.

This was not to be. Executive infighting led to a particularly dynamic org chart during the following financial cycle.
"If our particle accelerators could do that, it'd be like peeking into the mind of God."
descriptions.text2: - intercept, [REDACTED]

descriptions.text1: "And so did wrath fall like a thunderbolt, and the blow was felt by all of the Faithful, and by all of the unbelievers in the firmament. All then were a-murmur, near and far, and all did say 'Did you not hear a great shout of anger?'. But none could name its word, nor repeat it."
descriptions.text2: - The Book of Ludd, Visions 7:7

descriptions.text1: "A gamma ray burst preceded the discharge of unprecedented stream of... we must admit, EM sensors could not penetrate the plasma sheath and the gravimetric suite could not be calibrated under... yes, of course. My apologies. The physics team speculates ejecta is a stream of near-c charged matter-antimatter pseudoparticles annihilating in-situ in a... controlled, or perhaps semi-stable vortex. The baryonic asymmetry is unusual, to say the least."
descriptions.text2: - intercept, [REDACTED]

descriptions.text1: "The inverted ratio of baryogenesis - or shall we say antibaryogenesis - is among the more provocative qualities of the device. However, one suspects that management will be disinclined to appreciate the implications in light of the assessed firepower."
descriptions.text2: - intercept, [REDACTED]

descriptions.text1: "Sin feeds upon sin, evil feeds upon evil, ever fattening upon itself until nought of the soul remains."
descriptions.text2: - selection from the Archives of Holy Inquisition, Hesperus

descriptions.text1: "All command and tactical officers at risk of directly observing the phenomenon shall be required to perform their duties with a non-observing partner. When - not if - mesmerization manifests, the non-observing partner shall immediately execute remote display deactivation. This order stands until techops completes the automatic interrupt patch."
descriptions.text2: - intercept, [REDACTED]

skins.descriptionPrefix: After the Second AI War, many corrupted blueprints became available, sourced by salvagers willing to risk the star systems abandoned by Tri-Tachyon. Many of these were sold to disreputable elements such as black marketeers and pirates, who promptly put them back into service producing low quality but combat-capable ships.

Modified for operations in the Askonia system under orders from Supreme Executor Philip Andrada, this hull includes integrated solar shielding as well as a peculiar internal cladding provided by an industrial conglomerate out of Sindria itself. That the chief designer, appointed by the Supreme Executor for his many cycles of loyal service, sits on the board of that conglomerate is simply an example of the unity and efficiency of the Sindrian Polity.
Fanatics of the Luddic Path have made this ship their own, stripping out all unnecessary furnishing and transforming it into a haphazard vehicle of holy war.

This ship has been thoroughly overhauled by the Tri-Tachyon corporation. Tri-Tachyon compliant software patches have been installed which are fully integrated with TriPad (R) status monitoring protocols, high-spec flux conduit upgrades performed, and weapon attachment points refurbished for mounting advanced energy weapons.
Ships that would be decommissioned in quieter times now see widespread use throughout the Sector. The hull designation for such ships is usually tagged with a "D", for "damaged" or "defective".

This ship is on the Hegemony auxiliary list and as such its systems have been upgraded to military standard and a rigorous schedule of servicing enforced with the expectation that it can be pressed into military service during emergencies.
This ship has been given Luddic Church markings. Systems modifications are otherwise superficial.
This ship has been heavily modified - and poorly maintained - by its pirate crew.

A series of ambitious modifications have been made to this Venture in some dark shipyard on the outer rim. The hangar space and ore bays have been replaced by a hardpoint capable of mounting an enormous missile launcher, munitions storage, and a largely reliable generic autoloader system. The fact that this missile launcher is rear-facing has inspired a great number of colorful nicknames for this hull variant by crew and foe alike.
